body:
Hey Andre, I haven't had a chance to look at this closely, but I do really like the idea of this functionality. Some thoughts:
- Right now it looks like this is exposing catalyst `DataType` to end users.  While this maybe okay, the original intention was to keep the catalyst API purely internal to leave things flexible in the future.  Therefore, we may want to create wrapper classes in the public API that don't expose so many details (for example dataTypes have ClassTags that talk about the underlying JVM datatype that we use during execution).  Another option (maybe in addition to a programatic api) would be use use HiveQL strings to describe schema (there is already a converter).  At the very least we need to mark this method experimental though.  A task for me right now is to create a Java API for Spark SQL, and part of this will be deciding how to expose schema to end users.
- I looked the test that is failing.  I'm confused how `InsertIntoParquetTable` is sneaking into the Hive test cases.  Is something getting mixed up during analysis?  Are we just failing to reset some state in the reset function of TestHive?
- The above aside, I think the issue here is the second parameter list to `InsertIntoParquetTable`.  It is correct to keep the spark context in the second list so it is not consider part of the case class as far as equality is concerned, but arguments in other parameter lists are not included in the 'magic' tree copying and so need to be added manually `override def otherCopyArgs = sc :: Nil`.
- You may already handle these cases correctly, but a few things that came to mind.
  - What happens to existing RDDs when a table is appended to?  Is there an a case when recomputing will rescan the directory looking for files and cause the RDD to change?  Will this always happen?
  - What happens if multiple users append to a parquet "table", stored on HDFS for example, at the same time?

@mateiz I will update other `RDD[Array[Double]]`s in a separate PR to keep this one clean. Instead of putting the converter to `Vectors`, I create a new object `VectorRDDs` and put it there. Later we can add methods like `randn` to `VectorRDDs`.

Thanks, I've merged this into master and did a somewhat hairy backport into 0.9
This is obviously not a permanent solution as I imagine this makes our parser combinators even slower than they were before... but this is definitely better than it was before.

I feel conflicted about this -- I wonder if it's better to just never restart (i.e., when an exception gets thrown, end the SparkContext with an exception).  Have others seen examples of exceptions in the DAGScheduler that we can recover from?

I filed the JIRA leading to this change because a PythonAccumulator was throwing a SparkException (exposing this DAGScheduler issue).  I originally tried to fix the handling of this exception (see https://spark-project.atlassian.net/browse/SPARK-1290) but the exception gets thrown when the Python Spark Context gets disconnected from the Scala Spark Context -- so I don't think the problem can be recovered from.  In other words, for that case, I think it makes most sense to just die, because we're never going to make forward progress.

I'm also concerned that we can never completely clean up after an error like this.  For example, what if the exception gets thrown at the end of handling a task completion, where a job has already been marked as finished.  Then when we cancel the job, we'll end up with a bunch of duplicate messages.  I think I'm in favor of a solution where we fail the DAGScheduler on an exception, and then catch the recoverable exceptions in the appropriate place lower down in the code, where we can appropriately clean up the state.

Curious to hear what others' thoughts are here...
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Jenkins, this is ok to test.

I am far from an expert on this part of the code, but why not just terminate in this case rather than continue with the DAG scheudler in a potentially weird an inconsistent state.

An exception in the DAG scheduler is a serious failure which, in many cases, indicates the job is doomed and cannot complete anyways.

As is, this seems like it could create some really hard-to-debug situations where a user had a partial failure earlier on in their application then they see some weird behavior later and can't figure out what's going on.
Hey, sorry, github doesnt seem to be closing PR on branch 0.9 on its own. Can you close this.
Looks good to me, and tested the fix out on a UI. Thanks!

Generally I think it's best to catch exceptions as close to where they're
thrown as you can, but only if you can somehow "recover" from the
exception.  If the exception is unrecoverable though, let it go all the way
up to a catch-all for logging and then shut down the service as cleanly as
possible.

On Fri, Mar 21, 2014 at 5:08 PM, Patrick Wendell
notifications@github.comwrote:

> I am far from an expert on this part of the code, but why not just
> terminate in this case rather than continue with the DAG scheudler in a
> potentially weird an inconsistent state.
> 
> An exception in the DAG scheduler is a serious failure which, in many
> cases, indicates the job is doomed and cannot complete anyways.
> 
> As is, this seems like it could create some really hard-to-debug
> situations where a user had a partial failure earlier on in their
> application then they see some weird behavior later and can't figure out
> what's going on.
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/apache/spark/pull/186#issuecomment-38336957
> .
@mateiz @marmbrus does this need to update the programming guide (which currently says they are case sensitive in bold)?

Okay, you're persuading me.  I was thinking about exceptions being generated only by misbehaving jobs whose ill effects would only be present in the DAGScheduler.  Failures in the DAGScheduler itself we can at least hope to recover from if we can do sufficient cleanup of its state in the restart hooks, but if the exceptions are caused elsewhere in Spark, just surfacing first in the DAGScheduler, and require cleanup/restart actions outside of the DAGScheduler's control, then I think you are right, Kay, that even more extreme actions are called for.

In the future, we may want to look at whether we can cleanly segregate exceptions caught in the DAGScheduler into different levels of recoverability so we don't have to default to taking extreme actions that will kill the SparkContext, kill multiple jobs, etc.  But that's definitely not something that we can do for 0.9.1.
Created https://spark-project.atlassian.net/browse/SPARK-1295 to track this. Ideally we'd have "SPARK-1295: " prefixed to the PR name, but just linking it here should be OK.

Interesting, have you tried them without your change too? The PySpark accumulators are backed by Java ones, but maybe there's a problem with these being serialized too early or something. Do Java accumulators in general still work?

Alright, I'll push a commit to update the doc.

I agree this is not good for performance -- just make sure you don't add much longer SQL keywords, because the cost is exponential. Most definitely don't add [SEMANTICSIMILARITYDETAILSTABLE](http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms189822.aspx).
@mengxr do you want to update the API for the other ML algorithms to use Vector in this PR, or would you create a separate one?
I'd definitely go with just killing the SparkContext for now. We can still cancel the jobs to have them throw a SparkException in the appropriate thread. It's better behavior than what we have today.
@markhamstra I'd be okay if this doesn't support an async version right now since it's a tricky one to make async. It still seems useful as is.

All automated tests passed.
Refer to this link for build results: https://amplab.cs.berkeley.edu/jenkins/job/SparkPullRequestBuilder/13331/
I will create a separate PR for other ML algorithms.

Sure, these locally iterable results are useful even without async and the ability to cancel part way through the iteration; but that functionality is also very useful, so we shouldn't lose track of adding it to 1.1 or later.

The ability of https://github.com/apache/incubator-spark/pull/421 to batch the iteration up into more than just one partition per run job is also very useful and can provide significant performance benefits -- and that's not just speculation....

Hey @RongGu , I see you haven't yet addressed my comments about the "app ID" in https://github.com/apache/incubator-spark/pull/468. Please just generate a random folder name and have the same one for the executors and the driver right now. We can deal with making it match the app ID later (e.g. if we change cluster mode so that the SparkContext figures out its app ID before it starts).
Also as noted on that previous PR, if you do this, you won't need to pass an AppID throughout the code as you do now. You can put a property in the SparkConf object that already gets passed.

The Python accumulators still work on master and with the changes from #143 (which serializes the closure at closure cleaning but doesn't use the serialized value for anything).

As far as I can tell, accumulators in general still work after this change; at least all of the non-pyspark tests that use accumulators all still work after this change (I have been re-running `JavaAPISuite`, `AccumulatorSuite`, `DistributedSuite`, `ReplSuite`, and `AsyncRDDActionsSuite` individually while experimenting with this).

Mark, I agree with you, that you can benefit from fetching more than one partition per time. But let me explain why I choose more simple approach with only one partition per time. I don't want to think how much free memory I have on my process, which is the size of partition and calculate number of partitions per time. All I want  - escape OOM. And so I implement the most straightforward approach for it. Yes it has lack of configuration, but it's simple, short, reliable and do it's job)
About iterator instead of iterable - totally agree, good thought. Changed and retested.

I have test the original/1-version/2-version LR and SVM, here is the result:

(Note that original version runs 100 iterations, while the other two run 10 iterations with 10 local iterations.)

| Type | Time | Last 10 losses |
| --- | :-: | --: |
| original LR | 89.348 | 0.638 - 0.636 |
| 1-version LR | 13.094 | 1.769 - 0.636 |
| **2-version LR** | **10.747** | **1.618 - 0.631** |
| original SVM | 88.708 | 0.947 - 0.947 |
| 1-version SVM | 13.062 | 2.127 - 0.694 |
| **2-version SVM** | **10.829** | **1.943 - 0.691** |

There are 3 updaters : L1-updater, L2-updater, and simple updater, and 3 gradients: Logistic, Square and Hinge. SVM uses Hinge+L2, LR uses Logistic+simple, Lasso uses Square+L1.

But I encounter some difficulties in Lasso, I am still trying to fix them.
